Throughout the questionnaire, "Sandstone" means the area which is now Sandstone.

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Sandstone before 1932, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on this questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Sandstone archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Sandstone Archives Office,
University of Sandstone,
Sandstone, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Only one. The first year, 4 miles away.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? In 1886 we had a family half a mile away, 3 or 4 families, one had his sister to help care for the children.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? We visited each other quite often, especially in the summer months.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Yes, when there was a religious service, or other social event.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? No invitation as a rule.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually late afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Not unless we were on a long drive or were asked to stay for our safety.

Was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

Why to another part of the country while my husband was still teaching or farming work be made, whether at the day or not?

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? A cup of tea in the afternoon was offered, but I don't think it was a common practice.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Someone stayed home especially on visits.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, that was the common practice for a new comer, but we couldn't have anybody come over to help us.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Making a bee was the only way a man could raise the walls of a log house or put on a roof. Sometimes it was just a meeting of help for a few days, putting up a stable or grainery.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. No

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No, instead, we kept making a living or just getting along, but we didn't have parties on certain occasions when young fellows left for the town or to see their fortunes elsewhere.

After 1914 we had young people come in for a meal once a week to stay for a baseball game, sometimes we joined by others for square dancing till late in the night.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by two times a month, etc.? We ended our visits every two weeks, once a week, etc.

In 1914 we had many people come for a visit, but during the winter months, we rarely visited.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1936

What material was it made of? Frame

How large was it? About 20 by 60

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Church organization

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Close to church

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) School hall was not far apart but were used, but schools were easier to warm up in wintertime.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for? Babies were kept close together, babies were wrapped up to keep them warm.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? They were blankets & given hay until school started working.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Ring Pothole, Euchre, Whist

Has there card playing for a prize? Yes, when card parties were given to raise money for the church, etc.

What dances were popular? Square dances, waltzes & polkas

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

The church didn't want to get money from dancing parties, so folks had their own instead.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there those who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Card playing was always frowned upon.

At all times, we only played cards to raise money by betting, for the good reason that money was needed for the farm.

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? None at all in a new settlement.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. Chivarees were favored only when the married couple left in a hurry for their honeymoon without giving a party or dance. When they got back they got a real warm reception, such as surrounding the house by the couple was in, yelling, beating drums, etc.

Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable. One Christmas party given by Mr. W. Frost in 1886, we had games such as singing John Brown's body, adding one word at a time, adding drums for each verse, also guessing games such as What is it? Word or motion, hunt out the article in question on a person in the room or on well, they were given points if the answer didn't come right, one was the Post Office. It was an occasion for great delight. We had some ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

Let this next was a story told by Mrs. Olive Foster

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Each year the name of an article in the story, this one was about a man driving a harvest hay, & no matter who was chosen, he had chosen the harness, each give the date and reason for it being organized, had a part of the harness, in the story, the title used an article of the harness thus if something happened the traces, the hitches, the bit, etc.

How many women belonged? How often did it meet? Named, then went pay a forfeit.

22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

Skating when weather wasn't too cold.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? Days were shorter in the winter but we could tell the children stories, play cards, etc., after supper. We also had parties for family members who were visiting from other places which were helpful in keeping children amused.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

Only around Christmas, when presents of rubber balloons blowing them around was a sort of game kept everyone occupied.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

In 1886, we had our first picnic over Crooked Lake in beautiful valley on July 4th.

26. Who organized it?

My Elsie Kendrick, who came back from her travels to Yorkton so she had experience at outdoor events.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? As many as could come were welcome, Indian pow wows, Horses carrying weights for men, running, tug-of-war, potato races on the grass, we had to make sure even then.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? The people from as far as Yorkton but brought tents to sleep overnight. After dark we all went to large bonfire close by, we danced to the music played by the brass band, harmonica, accordion, lights were from lanterns.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Changed for general lunch by joining my Kendrick sisters in bringing what was most needed in the food line, the ladies had cooked plenty of wild ducks, also sliced ham.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Nothing very fancy on account of the distance to carry things, homemade to think made on the spot in large crocks, no charge. No doubt the ladies had provided for that as it was for a small crowd.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? We all got there for the midday meal, we who had come about 15 PM. Kendrick we left with them to the Yorkton crowd the next morning. Then left after the dance at night. It was a 50 mile drive to Yorkton, about 10 miles to Kendrickview, that's the town where Mrs. Kendrick had gone for her goods.

33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Sleeping in the largest tent, being bitten by fleas and other insects, laughing and crying like children at play until all hours of the night. The feet of the sand, making cliffs, it was an adventure never to be forgotten. Now,反射，our parents had stayed home to do the chores, so we young girls had no one to look after our well-being, such as knitting or crafts.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

The next one was held at Cotham—name of our settlement—in 1885 but I couldn't describe it for I didn't live there any more, being married to a school teacher. For Indian Reserve—had been moved around once already, arriving late to this picnic, close to Butten's Bay Cottage, I saw Percy Hocken being thrown from his horse very, but he wasn't much hurt, from broadcast that day.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

No more picnics for us till we settled at Mt. Hubert. Then we came at Summerberry but among the rising, a family I couldn't attend, our children of school age went to school some Sundays, etc., a twist towards feeding the hungry crowd, School Rides for their parents.

Sleeping in the largest tent, being bitten by flies rather than insects, laughing and crying like cyclones of bullets till all hours of the night. The feel of the early morning chill, it was an experience never to be forgotten. Now, my parents had stayed home to look after the chores, so we young girls had no one to look after our well-being, such as buttering our wraps.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

The next one was held at Coteau, name of our settlement in 1885 but I couldn't describe it. Food didn't have any name, being served to the school teachers. On Indian Reserve, we'd been moved around once already, arriving late to this picnic, close to getting by cottages. I saw Percy Thorburn being thrown from his racing pony, but he wasn't much hurt, there must have been a few from Broadway that day.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

No more picnics for us till we moved at St. Hubert. Then we came at Summerberry but among the young, a family I couldn't stand, our children of school age went to school some sandstone, as a half-truck feeding the horses. School kids, their parents.
